1	EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5
Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR A§68
California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR A§5189
Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR A§1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.

This program is intended to be a "living document".  As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary.  To accomplish this, Pandol & Sons has elected to use PSMWriter©, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc.  This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 

1.1	PANDOL & SONS, RISK & PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PROGRAM 

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Pandol & Sons has updated/developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name 	        Process Chemical	Process Quantity(lbs)
Ammonia Refrigeration	Ammonia (Anhydrous)	34,000

Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety.  The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals.  Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid physical property damage.

Pandol & Sons has an exemplary safety record, one that we are quite proud of.  Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety.  We have: 

1.	Prepared a unified pro

gram based on the PSM plan to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
2.	Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general Pandol & Sons business practices
3.	Utilized PSMWriter© software to ensure that all necessary Pandol & Sons employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)

The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures and practices that will help our employees protect themselves and our neighbors.

1.2	PROCESS DESCRIPTION

Pandol and Sons Cold Storage operates a commercial cold storage facility for table grapes. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigerating capacity to ten (10) cold storage rooms, seven (7) precool rooms, three (3) mini-rooms, and a shipping area.  The rooms utilize bunker mounted evaporator coils that contain chilled liquid ammonia.  A computer system provides substantial control and alarm capability.

The system operates as follows: high pressure liquid from the high pressure receiver is piped to each flooded zone of refrigeration, where it passes through a solenoid valve, an expansion valve, and into a low temperature & pressure accumulator vessel mounted behind the bunker wall. From the accumulators, cold liquid ammonia is circulated through evaporator coils. As heat is absorbed, the liquid ammonia vaporizes to form low temperature & pressure gas which is returned to the accumulator vessels. The ammonia vapor is returned from the accumulator vessels through a suction return line to our main suction accumulator in the engine room.  From there, it passes through the compressors. The high pressure discharge from the compressors is sent to water cooled evaporative condensers where the high pressure gas ammonia is cooled, liquefied and returned to our high pressure receiver.  Liquid separated from the suction return gas in the main suction accumulator drains into the liquid transfer vessel.  Operation of a float switch activated solenoid valve raises the pressu

re in the liquid transfer vessels to the point the liquid can be drained into the high pressure receivers.

The facility was originally built in the 1970's. Since then the following significant projects have occurred:

1. Mid 1990's - B&W Refrigeration increased the  of the evaporator coils, accumulators, fans, and control valves in Storage Rooms 1-8
2. 1996 - B&W Refrigeration installed the refrigeration equipment for the Shipping Room
3. Early 2000's - B&W Refrigeration increased the  of the evaporator coils, accumulators, fans, and control valves in Precool 1 and 2

The system contain numerous safety devices including sensors which stop the compressors if temperatures or pressures exceed or drop below established limits, and safety relief valves which vent ammonia gas to the atmosphere if the pressure in the system exceeds their set point.  Lastly, an emergency "dump box" contains switches and valves to turn off equipment and vent ammonia if necessary.

The ammonia system at our facility consists of vessels which are interconnected, or which are co-located such that a release of ammonia could impact the ability to operate vessels that are not directly connected. Therefore, we are treating the system as a single process.

1.3	GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE & CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

1.3.1	GENERAL 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings.  During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.
Pandol & Sons has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process.  These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release.  The results of the analyses are reported in the body of the program. 

1.3.2	ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Pandol &

Sons facility is an integral part of the overall business and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner.  Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.
Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep an active log book of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia.  In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4	FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

Pandol & Sons has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5	EMERGENCY ACTION AND RESPONSE PLAN

Pandol & Son's emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

California "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 8 CCR A§3220
Federal "Emergency Action Plan" - Title 29 CFR A§1910.38 
California "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 8 CCR Title 8 A§5192(q)
Federal "Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response" (HAZWOPER) - Title 29 CFR A§1910.120(q)

Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.

1.6	PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Our company has an outstanding safety record, one that we are quite proud of. Many policies and procedures have been implemented to promote overall plant, worker and public safety.  Nevertheless, Pandol & Sons continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter© software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Pandol & Son's ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors.  In addition, PSMWriter© track

s all RMP-PSM related events so that Pandol & Son's management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.
Pandol & Sons has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program.  When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter©, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date.  Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter© as well.  A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter©.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter© to create, schedule, track, and document events, Pandol & Sons has also entered into a contract with California Controlled Atmosphere to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation. A copy of Resource Compliance's service agreement has been included in this program with the support material.

For the future, Pandol & Sons now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document".  It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Pandol & Sons employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement.  Through the RMP-PSM program Pandol & Sons will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
